Comments_List: Many different aspects of current immunological research as well as a basis for where this field came from.
I developed a comprehensive knowledge of the human immune system.
The fundamental conceptual framework of the immune system; The logic of the organization of immune functions.

The multitude of lecturers made it a bit discordant with other lectures in the course, so that individual topics were either skimmed over too much or lost in translation between lectures. Some lectures were fantastic while others were less organized and more chaotic with how topics were overviewed. The best lectures seemed to have a common theme: a very good basis in the course reader for material to be covered, an overview of what was to be covered in that class lecture, and use of summarizing very key points through bullet points after a long discussion on a single topic. Other lectures mentioned many different ideas or concepts, and failed to really emphasize what the key takeaway for learning about a certain topic.

The course could be improved by having the instructors talk to each other about what was covered. Several times during the course the current instructor would repeat topics or be unaware of what had been taught. 
More detailed feedback on exam questions would also be helpful.

Strengths:
The course itself is so precious because some of the lecturers are exactly the researcher that made the discovery introduced in the lecture; Most lectures were well organized and also fascinating; we learned not only the knowledge and concepts but also some invaluable advice on doing research.

Weakness:
The order of the lectures could be better arranged for a more holistic understanding of the big picture. Although I understand this could be hard due to the schedule of the lecturers.

A weakness is that this course is directed for students in Immunology with experience in Immunology and not for anyone with a general interest in Immunology with a want for a better understanding of the field.

I don't know. As I said, I feel that the course itself was a bit erratic in the quality of the lectures as well as a lack of true discussion revolving around the papers that were "required" reading. Also, the grading was on the poor end, as it took ages to get homeworks returned or the one midterm returned, and even then one entire essay question was missing, thus causing the test to lose an entire 10 points. However, since overall it is a true survey of immunology and the current research, it is a useful course, although not executed in the most efficient or productive way.
If the student was interested in the subject matter, then I would absolutely recommend this course. It is very comprehensive, and it is well taught.
Yes! Any student interested in immunology should definitely take this course, with both textbook discoveries introduced by the researcher who made it, and cutting-edge perspectives of the field.
I would not recommend this course unless the student has prior experience in Immunology.
